head.title: Hierarchical Chestnut-Burr Like Structure of Copper Cobalt Oxide Electrocatalyst Directly Grown on Ni Foam for Anion Exchange Membrane Water Electrolysis | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Hierarchical Chestnut-Burr Like Structure of Copper Cobalt Oxide Electrocatalyst Directly Grown on Ni Foam for Anion Exchange Membrane Water Electrolysis

Uniquely nanostructured CuCo2O4 is presented as an electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reactions (OER). CuCo2O4 particles in a chestnut-burr-like shape (CCO*, where ∗ = chestnut burr) were hydrothermally synthesized around fibers of Ni foam substrates as current collectors. Chestnut burrs 4 μm on average had thorns consisting of less than five threads. Each thread was made of a consecutive array of nanobeads less than 10 nm. Nanovoids or nanopores were found between nanobeads. The chestnut-burr structure of CCO* allowed IrO2-overwhelming OER activity. By using the hierarchically nanostructured electrocatalyst directly grown on current collectors without binders and conducting agents, high performances of anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis was demonstrated. Three merits of the electrode architecture were emphasized. First, mass transfer pathways for reactants and products were secured in a microscale between thorns and in a nanoscale between nanobeads. Second, more active sites were exposed to electrolytes in the hierarchical structure. Third, direct growth of active materials on conductive substrates improved adhesion and electrical conduction.

div.p:
Uniquely nanostructured CuCo
2
O
4
is presented as an electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reactions (OER). CuCo
2
O
4
particles in a chestnut-burr-like shape (CCO*, where ∗ = chestnut burr) were hydrothermally synthesized around fibers of Ni foam substrates as current collectors. Chestnut burrs 4 μm on average had thorns consisting of less than five threads. Each thread was made of a consecutive array of nanobeads less than 10 nm. Nanovoids or nanopores were found between nanobeads. The chestnut-burr structure of CCO* allowed IrO
2
-overwhelming OER activity. By using the hierarchically nanostructured electrocatalyst directly grown on current collectors without binders and conducting agents, high performances of anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis was demonstrated. Three merits of the electrode architecture were emphasized. First, mass transfer pathways for reactants and products were secured in a microscale between thorns and in a nanoscale between nanobeads. Second, more active sites were exposed to electrolytes in the hierarchical structure. Third, direct growth of active materials on conductive substrates improved adhesion and electrical conduction.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: The unique structure of directly grown CCO* (CCO*, where* = chestnut burr) providing binder-free and conducting agent-free benefits and allowing exceptionally high loading on substrates dramatically enhanced electroactivities of OER for efficient electrolysis.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Electrochemical processes are described by both intensive and extensive parameters. Intensive parameters such as standard rate constant (
k
°) and transfer coefficient (α) are determined by the nature of reactions defined by reactants and products. Extensive parameters depend on system size such as electrode area and amount of reactants. Electrocatalytic processes are electrochemical ones whose kinetics are accelerated by catalysts. Here,
k
° becomes larger due to the activation energy (
E
a
) reduced by catalysts so that overall kinetics are improved. The kinetic improvement in the intensive parameter is determined by chemical and crystallographic identities of electrocatalysts. For example, ruthenium (Ru) and iridium (Ir) are most electrocatalytic in an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) among metallic catalysts, while tungsten (W) and gold (Au) are much worse than ruthenium. It is difficult to defeat the OER electroactivities of Ru/Ir by using other materials in terms of intensive activities (e.g., activity of a single active site). The only way to make overall kinetics of low-activity catalysts approach that of high-activity catalysts is to increase the number of active sites in a defined apparent area. However, the amount of active sites cannot increase infinitely because the access of reactants to active sites is restricted in high loadings. Therefore, designing and organizing catalyst particles to secure efficient mass and electron transfers is overwhelmingly important.

Water electrolysis has been suggested as one of the hydrogen production system, following steam reforming,
(1,2)
photoproduction,
(3)
and fossil fuel and gas extraction. Among these methods for production of hydrogen, the most attractive merit of water electrolysis is its high efficiency and the generation of high purity hydrogen without environmental pollution.
(4,5)
Nowadays, two main water electrolysis methods are currently used such as alkaline water electrolysis and proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE). The case of alkaline water electrolysis has long been commercialized due to its nonprecious metal catalysts and easy handing. But, the liquid electrolyte-based system causes disadvantage such as low stability, relatively low hydrogen purity, and electrolyte leakage. Another water electrolysis system, PEMWE, has the advantages of generation of high purity hydrogen and high efficiency and safety.
(6)
However, this system operates in a low pH atmosphere and requires the use of precious metal catalysts for high efficiency. Therefore, the cost is a drawback in commercialization.
(7)
Considering the pros and cons of the two systems mentioned above, the anion exchange membrane water electrolysis system (AEMWE) has recently been developed as an alternative.
(8,9)
The AEMWE system operates in alkaline media, which means that nonprecious metal catalysts can be used, thereby reducing costs. It is also possible to produce high purity hydrogen using solid electrolytes such as PEMWE. However, since the performance is lower than other water electrolysis methods, it is urgent to develop a high efficiency nonprecious metal catalyst to overcome this problem. The electrocatalysts are required for AEMWE to hasten the slow kinetics of OER. Noble metal catalysts including Ir, Ru, and Au are not appropriate for electrolysis because of of high costs and environmental problems. Oxide catalysts based on cheaper transition metals have been considered as OER catalysts, including M
x
Co
3–x
O
4
(M = Mn, Ni, Cu, and Zn) having spinel structures.
(10−12)

Practical electrode architectures are based on coatings of mixtures of catalysts, conducting agents, and binders on flat current collectors. Catalysts directly grown on porous current collectors have demonstrated successful electrocatalytic performances.
(13)
This single-component-on-collector architecture is considered energy-density efficient and cost effective in that binders and additional conducting agents were not used. Also, the direct growth possibly supports better electrical integration of active materials to substrates (current collectors), guaranteeing fast electron transport through interfaces between directly grown active materials and their substrates. Architectures based on the direct growth have been used for lithium ion batteries,
(14−16)
lithium–air batteries,
(17)
and supercapacitors.
(18−20)
However, they were not applied yet to AEMWE systems.

Here, we present a binder-free and conducting-agent-free architecture of anode electrodes containing transition metal oxide catalysts for AEMWE. Copper cobalt oxide in spinel (CuCo
2
O
4
or CCO) was grown directly on wired current collectors. A unique nanostructure was developed, which has a chestnut-burr-like shape. Here, 3 μm-sized chestnut burrs were deposited on Ni foam, while their thorns were made of ∼10 nm spherical crystallites of CCO. There were no serious electrode integration problems developed even if binders were not used. The OER was confirmed by using the chestnut-burr-like CCO (CCO*, where ∗ indicates the chestnut-burr-like shape). This study not only compared the catalytic activity of the synthesized CCO catalyst but it also directly configured a full cell for the AEMWE system to confirm the performance of the practical hydrogen production.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
CCO* particles were successfully synthesized by a hydrothermal process and heat treatment in the presence of microfibrous networks of Ni foam (
Figure S1
). The synthesis process of directly grown CCO* on Ni foam is shown in
Figure
1
.

div.p: Figure 1. Schematic illustration for synthesis of CCO* on Ni foam. The bottom picture indicates an actual synthesized electrode.

div.div:
Chestnut-burr-like shapes of CCO* particles were confirmed around Ni foam (
Figure
2
a and b). Chestnut burrs in an identical dimension (diameter = 4 μm in average) were grown on the substrate. Thornes of the chestnut burrs consisted of less than five threads (
Figure
2
c). Each thread was made of a consecutive array of nanobeads less than 10 nm in size (
Figure
2
d). Nanovoids or nanopores were found between nanobeads, which were thought to be generated by gaseous products resulting from decomposition of organic components during annealing. The chestnut-burr structure appears to provide macroscopic mass transfer pathways to OER. In addition, the porosity of thorns possibly has reactants reach active sites of CCO* nanobeads in a more efficient way. Elements constituting CCO* (Cu, Co, and O) were found on thorns of chestnut burrs in elemental maps (
Figure
2
e–g).

div.p: Figure 2. Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image. (a, b) CCO* directly grown on Ni foam. (c) Part of thorns in a chestnut-burr particle. (d) Four threads in a thorn consisting of nanobeads. (e–g) EDX elemental mapping image of a needle-like part of CCO*, showing a homogeneous dispersion of Cu, Co, and O species.

div.div:
The material of chestnut burrs was identified as CuCo
2
O
4
in spinel. X-ray diffraction patterns of CuCo
2
O
4
in spinel (JCPDS: 37-0878) were obtained from CCO* grown on Ni foam (
Figure
3
a). No impurity peaks were observed except of the copper oxide-related peaks at 35.6°, 38.6°, 48.7°, and 61.5°. Each nanobead of thorns showed clear fringes with interlayer spacing at 0.28 nm corresponding to a lattice spacing of the (220) plane of CuCo
2
O
4
in spinel (
Figure S2
).
(21)
The molar ratio of Co to Cu was estimated around 2 by energy dispersive spectroscopy (
Figure S2
). The elemental composition of CuCo
2
O
4
was additionally supported by X-ray photoelectron spectra (
Figure S3
). The peak areas corresponding to elements were estimated at Cu:Co:O = 10.1%:21.0%:48.1%. Binding energies of peaks assigned to Cu 2p and Co 2p of CCO* in X-ray photoelectron spectra coincided with those of CuCo
2
O
4
in spinel (
Figure
3
b and c). The binding energy difference between the Co2P
1/2
and Co2P
3/2
peak is 15.3 eV, and the deconvoluted peaks could be best fitted to the spinel oxides of Co
2+
and Co
3+
.
(22)
Both results are consistent with that of CuCo
2
O
4
materials.
(23,24)
In the case of the spinel structure, transition metals with single electrons at the octahedral site catalytically provide more active sites for oxygen electrocatalysis.
(10)
Therefore, Co
3+
in a spinel-structured Co-based electrocatalyst acts as an active site. As shown in
Figure
3
d, this data presents high-resolution XPS O 1s spectra for CCO* and were deconvoluted into several peaks. In the O 1s spectra, the major peak at 529.4 eV is attributed to the M-O-M bonding energy (O
L
) which is a typical metal–oxygen bond because of the large amount of oxygen in the lattice, and the peak (O
OH
) at 529.9 eV is associated with hydroxyl groups or surface-adsorbed oxygen. The peak (O
V
) at 531.0 eV is attributed to an oxygen defect with a low oxygen coordination, and the peak at 531.8 eV is related to surface-adsorbed water molecules.
(25,26)

div.p:
Figure 3. CCO* identification. (a) X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of CCO* on Ni foam. (b) X-ray photoelectron high resolution spectra (XPS) of Cu 2p. (c) XPS spectra of Co 2p. Binding energy difference between Co 2p
3/2
and Co 2p
2/1
peaks is 15.3 eV, corresponding to that of CuCo
2
O
4
in spinel. (d) XPS spectra of O 1s.

div.div:
As shown in
Figure
4
a, the experiment was carried out in a three-electrode system to measure the electrocatalytic activity of CCO* on Ni foam with Pt and Hg/HgO as a counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. OER activity of CCO* was superior to that of IrO
2
in the same alkaline media (
Figure
4
b). It is a surprising result when considering that IrO
2
is one of the best OER catalysts. OER polarization of greater than IrO
2
was obtained from CCO*, demonstrating the higher current density potential at same potential range as commercial IrO
2
. To observe the electocatalytic effect of Ni foam, Ni foam was performed for OER in a half-cell test. The OER performance can be seen to come almost from the electrocatalyst layer. For measuring OER stability, the potential was measured at a constant current at 100 mV s
–1
for 20 h. The potential catalyzed by CCO* did not change significantly after 20 h. On the other hand, commercial IrO
2
shows a sudden potential change after a durability test. During the durability test, it was confirmed that stable oxygen bubbles were generated continuously (inset graph in
Figure
4
c and picture). Comparing the durability, CCO* was better than IrO
2
. The first reason is that CCO* has increased the number of active sites because its unique structure leads to good durability with high catalytic activity.
(22)
The second reason is that IrO
2
is fixed to the substrate with Nafion as a binder. It has a relatively weak bonding force, so that IrO
2
is easily detached from the substrate during the oxygen evolution reaction. However, since the CCO* was directly grown on the substrate, it is physically strongly bonded between the electrocatalyst and the substrate. Therefore, there is almost no degradation in performance due to physical detachment of CCO*. The morphological benefits of CCO* allowed its OER activities to be superior to reported values of CuCo
2
O
4
spinel: 100 mA/cm
2
of OER polarization = 1.609 V
RHE
for CCO* versus 1.72 V
RHE
for CCO microflowers
(27)
or 1.62 V
RHE
for CCO nanosheets
(28)
or 1.633 V
RHE
for CCO nanowire.
(29)

div.p:
Figure 4. OER on CCO* versus IrO
2
. (a) Schematic illustration of cell configuration for half-cell test. (b) OER polarization in 1 M KOH (aq). (c) OER chronopoteniometry at 100 mA/cm
2
in 1 M KOH (aq). Photograph of (d) shows oxygen evolution during durability test.

div.div:
The kinetic gains of OER by using CCO* are thought to come from the chestnut-burr-like nanostructure of CCO* (
Figure
5
). First, mass transfer pathways for reactants and products were secured in two different scales: microscale pathways between thorns and nanoscale pathways between nanobeads. Second, more active sites exposed to the electrolyte is guaranteed by the hierarchical structure of the chestnut burr. Following the microscale and nanoscale pathways, reactants could meet active sites of CCO*. Third, direct growth of active materials on conductive substrates improved adhesion and electrical conduction, removing additional binders and conducting agents.
(30)

div.p: Figure 5. Schematic illustration of process for OER (oxygen generation) of AEMWE by using CCO* on Ni foam anode electrode. Chestnut-burr-like nanostructure of CCO* plays a crucial role during the electrolyte and air diffusion because of nanobead structure and a mass of active site via hierarchical structure. CCO* on Ni foam electrode shows good ionic and charge transfer abilities.

div.div:
A full cell test was performed to confirm the possibility of using the synthesized catalyst in an actual system. CCO* on Ni foam was used as an anode electrode to develop an AEMWE cell.
Figure
6
a shows the electrode and components that were used in the experiment.
Figure
6
b shows the polarization curve after cell activation using CCO* and IrO
2
as anode electrodes. The IrO
2
electrode exhibited a current density of approximately 875 mA/cm
2
at 1.8 V
cell
. This performance is similar to results of recent studies that used IrO
2
as an the anode. Although CCO* as an anode electrode had a higher onset potential than IrO
2
, it exhibited a higher current density in the high-potential area. As such, it is believed that the structure of the CCO* electrode, which consists of nanosized particles, is effective at reducing mass transfer loss in the high-potential area where oxygen bubbles are generated. As shown in
Figure S5
, the electrode with the adjusted loading amount was applied to the AEMWE cell by using the synthesized CCO (CuCo
2
O
4
, not CCO*) nanoparticle. As the loading amount increased, the mass transfer at the high potential region decreased. The amount of active sites cannot increase infinitely because the access of reactants to active sites is restricted in high loadings. The thicker catalyst layer resulting from high catalyst loading causes mass transport resistance. As a result, the stable loading method by the direct growth method and the unique structure of the catalyst did not cause mass transfer loss problems despite the high loading amount. Therefore, designing and organizing catalyst particles to secure efficient mass and electron transfers is overwhelmingly important. A current of 1400 mA/cm
2
was measured at 1.9 V
cell
, and this is the highest performance among electrocatalysts that are used in currently reported AEMs among the AEMWE cells that use nonprecious metals as anode electrodes (
Figure
6
d). For a durability test of AEMWE, a high current density of 500 mA/cm
2
was applied to a single cell for 12 h as shown in
Figure
6
c. For generation of continuous hydrogen in an actual AEMWE system, a current density of 400–500 mA/cm
2
is required. The AEMWE fabricated with CCO* showed good durability properties. The initial overvoltage of AEMWE was 1.696 V
cell
and gradually increased to 1.718 V
cell
as the stability test progressed, which means that AEMWE maintained about 98.7% of the initial amount. The amount of generated hydrogen was measured in real time, and the energetic efficiency of the AEMWE cell was measured using
eq 1
.
(1)
where
V
H
2
is the volume of hydrogen gas,
H
0
is the calorific value of hydrogen (10.8 × 10
6
J m
–3
, lower heating value), and
W
h
is the electric power to produce hydrogen. An increase in voltage caused by cell decline led to reduced hydrogen generation efficiency, but this system maintained a high hydrogen generation efficiency that was about 80% of the efficiency of the initial period (
Figure S4
). In the AEMWE system to which CCO* on Ni foam is applied, a video of hydrogen generation is shown in the
Supporting Information
.

div.p:
Figure 6. (a) Photograph of components of AEMWE cell. (b) Polarization curves of AEMWE cell using CCO* (23 mg cm
–2
) on Ni foam and IrO
2
(4 mg cm
–2
) catalyst as anode and Pt/C (1 mg cm
–2
) as cathode in 1 M KOH at 45 °C. (c) Galvanostatic curves of AEMWE cell using CCO* on Ni foam and Pt/C electrodes at a current density of 500 mA cm
–2
for 12 h in 1 M KOH at 45 °C. Inset image in (c) is a evolved hydrogen bubble at cathode tube (See the video in the
Supporting Information
). (d) Comparison of the reported AEMWE’s performance with anode/cathode electrocatalyst system.
(8,9,31−45)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The chestnut-burr-like structure of the CuCo
2
O
4
electrocatalyst (CCO*) was directly grown on Ni foam substrates, having hierarchical mass transfer pathways. The unique structure of CCO* providing binder-free and conducting agent-free benefits and allowing exceptionally high loading on substrates dramatically enhanced electroactivities of OER without cracking the electrode (
Figure S6
). The efficient operation of AEMWE was successfully demonstrated with small overpotentials developed along with durability performance. The well-designed structure of CCO* and its direct growth on a current collector were proved to be an efficiently working architecture for electrochemical processes, enabling precious metal-free electrodes and then bringing further development to the oxygen electrochemistry-based electrolysis field.

A review. Hydrogen is considered to be the most viable energy carrier for the future. Producing hydrogen from ethanol steam reforming would not only be environmentally friendly but also would open new opportunities for utilization of renewable resources, which are globally available. This paper reviews the current state of the steam reforming process of ethanol, examines different catalysts, and, finally, makes a comparative anal. Different catalysts were used for the steam reforming of ethanol. Depending on the type of catalysts, reaction conditions, and the catalyst prepn. method, ethanol conversion and hydrogen prodn. vary greatly. Co/ZnO, ZnO, Rh/Al2O3, Rh/CeO2, and Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 performed the best, in regard to the steam reforming of ethanol. Currently, hydrogen prodn. from ethanol steam reforming is still in the research and development stage.

Because of the existence of infrastructures all around the world, the use of fossil resources as raw materials for hydrogen prodn. can be a midterm soln. in the implementation of hydrogen as a transport fuel. Therefore, the fuel processing technol. used for the prodn. of hydrogen should produce the lowest amt. of greenhouse gases, with the highest energy efficiency and the lowest environmental impact. In this work, several options for hydrogen prodn. from fossil fuels are evaluated: steam reforming, autothermal reforming of hydrocarbons, coal gasification, and methane decompn. A system for the capture of CO2 is supposed to be integrated in the reforming and gasification processes. This study evaluates the overall life cycle greenhouse gas emissions, the fossil energy consumption, and the environmental impact for the current and future energy scenarios. The autothermal reforming, decompn. of natural gas, and coal gasification are the best options from all of the points of view, while extrapolations to future scenarios predict very similar impacts. The economic anal. of methane decompn. processes reveals that the carbon selling price and the conversion of methane are the main factors influencing the cost-efficiency of produced hydrogen.

A review. Alk. water electrolysis is one of the easiest methods for hydrogen prodn., offering the advantage of simplicity. The challenges for widespread use of water electrolysis are to reduce energy consumption, cost and maintenance and to increase reliability, durability and safety. This literature review examines the current state of knowledge and technol. of hydrogen prodn. by water electrolysis and identifies areas where R&D effort is needed in order to improve this technol. Following an overview of the fundamentals of alk. water electrolysis, an elec. circuit analogy of resistances in the electrolysis system is introduced. The resistances are classified into three categories, namely the elec. resistances, the reaction resistances and the transport resistances. This is followed by a thorough anal. of each of the resistances, by means of thermodn. and kinetics, to provide a scientific guidance to minimising the resistance in order to achieve a greater efficiency of alk. water electrolysis. The thermodn. anal. defines various electrolysis efficiencies based on theor. energy input and cell voltage, resp. These efficiencies are then employed to compare different electrolysis cell designs and to identify the means to overcome the key resistances for efficiency improvement. The kinetic anal. reveals the dependence of reaction resistances on the alk. concn., ion transfer, and reaction sites on the electrode surface, the latter is detd. by the electrode materials. A quant. relationship between the cell voltage components and c.d. is established, which links all the resistances and manifests the importance of reaction resistances and bubble resistances. The important effect of gas bubbles formed on the electrode surface and the need to minimise the ion transport resistance are highlighted. The historical development and continuous improvement in the alk. water electrolysis technol. are examd. and different water electrolysis technologies are systematically compared using a set of the practical parameters derived from the thermodn. and kinetic analyses. In addn. to the efficiency improvements, the needs for redn. in equipment and maintenance costs, and improvement in reliability and durability are also established. The future research needs are also discussed from the aspects of electrode materials, electrolyte additives and bubble management, serving as a comprehensive guide for continuous development of the water electrolysis technol.

Ultra-pure hydrogen to feed a low temp. Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) or a high temp. Solid Oxide Fuel Cell (SOFC) can be produced by water electrolysis, either in a Proton Exchange Membrane Electrolysis Cell (PEMEC) working at low temps. (25-110 °C) or in a Solid Oxide Electrolysis Cell (SOEC) working at high temps. (600-950 °C). Both processes will be presented and discussed comparatively in terms of energy efficiencies, taking into account the working conditions at a low (70-80 °C) or a high (800 °C) temp. and at a given c.d., conditions which are far from the thermodn. equil. (no current flowing). Conversely to what is often written in the literature, the elec. energy efficiency of a SOEC never exceeds 100% and is comparable to that of a PEMEC, reaching in both cases 60-70% depending on the working conditions. In addn. the elec. efficiency of a hydrogen/oxygen fuel cell working at a low temp. (PEMFC) or high temp. (SOFC) will be calcd. allowing us to evaluate the round-trip energy efficiency of a hydrogen redox battery, such as a Unitized Regenerative Fuel Cell (URFC) for storage of intermittent energy. Some exptl. examples of URFC working at low (PEM) or high (SOC) temps. from recent publications will be presented and their energy efficiency will be estd. according to our theor. calcns.

Proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE) is an advanced and effective soln. to the primary energy storage technologies. A better understanding of performance and durability of PEMWE is crit. for the engineers and researchers to further advance this technol. for its market penetration, and for the manufacturers of PEM water electrolyzers to implement quality control procedures for the prodn. line or on-site process monitoring/diagnosis. This paper reviews the published works on performance degrdns. and mitigation strategies for PEMWE. Sources of degrdn. for individual components are introduced. With degrdn. causes discussed and degrdn. mechanisms examd., the review emphasizes on feasible strategies to mitigate the components degrdn. To avoid lengthy real lifetime degrdn. tests and their high costs, the importance of accelerated stress tests and protocols is highlighted for various components. In the end, R&D directions are proposed to move the PEMWE technol. forward to become a key element in future energy scenarios.

The authors report high-performance, durable alk. membrane H2O electrolysis in a solid-state cell. An anion exchange membrane (AEM) and catalyst layer ionomer for hydroxide ion conduction were used without the addn. of liq. electrolyte. At 50°, an AEM electrolysis cell using Ir oxide as the anode catalyst and Pt black as the cathode catalyst exhibited a c.d. of 399 mA/cm2 at 1.80 V. The durability of the AEM-based electrolysis cell could be improved by incorporating a highly durable ionomer in the catalyst layer and optimizing the H2O feed configuration. Cu incorporated Co3O4 (CuxCo3-xO4, 0 ≤ x < 1) nanoparticles were prepd. using a thermal decompn. method. Properties of the CuxCo3-xO4, such as morphol., particle sizes, crystallite structure and cation distribution, were characterized with SEM, TEM, XRD and EDX. The CuxCo3-xO4 particles, with various x values, are cubic spinel nanoparticles, with av. size of 20-30 nm. Incorporation of Cu in the spinel lattice of Co3O4 shifted the Co3+/Co4+ redox peak as well as the onset point for OER to more neg. potentials, which may be related to inversion of Cu2+ into the octahedral sites. Amongst all samples studied, Cu0.7Co2.3O4 was the most active for OER. The CuxCo3-xO4 electrodes exhibited satisfying stability during repetitive cyclic voltammetry. A membrane electrode assembly, using 3 mg cm-2 Cu0.7Co2.3O4 on the anode, demonstrated, in an alk. membrane H2O electrolyzer, a high c.d. performance of 1 A cm-2 at a voltage of 1.8 V in 1 mol dm-3 KOH at 25°.

Spinel-structured transition metal oxides are promising non-precious-metal electrocatalysts for oxygen electrocatalysis in rechargeable metal-air batteries. Porous cobalt manganese oxide (CMO) nanocubes are applied as the cathode electrocatalyst in rechargeable seawater batteries, which are a hybrid-type Na-air battery with an open-structured cathode and a seawater catholyte. The porous CMO nanocubes were synthesized by the pyrolysis of a Prussian blue analog, Mn3[Co(CN)6]2·nH2O, during air-annealing, which generated numerous pores between the final spinel-type CMO nanoparticles. The porous CMO electrocatalyst improved the redox reactions, such as the oxygen evolution/redn. reactions, at the cathode in the seawater batteries. The battery that used CMO displayed a voltage gap of ∼0.53 V, relatively small compared to that of the batteries employing com. Pt/C (∼0.64 V) and Ir/C (∼0.73 V) nanoparticles and without any catalyst (∼1.05 V) at the initial cycle. This improved performance was due to the large surface area (catalytically active sites) and the high oxidn. states of the randomly distributed Co and Mn cations in the CMO. Using a hard carbon anode, the Na-metal-free seawater battery exhibited a good cycle performance with an av. discharge voltage of ∼2.7 V and a discharge capacity of ∼190 mAh g-1hardcarbon during 100 cycles (energy efficiencies of 74-79%).

Herein the authors report a facile and direct synthesis of porous NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays (NWAs) with robust mech. adhesion to conductive electrodes by a simple two-step method. Upon complete pyrolysis of the Co-Ni-hydroxide precursor, high-quality cryst. NiCo2O4 is achieved. The porous NiCo2O4 nanowires are highly active for catalytic H2O oxidn. when serving as the working electrodes without any external materials (binder and/or C black), as evidenced by exhibiting higher catalytic c.d. for H2O oxidn. compared to precious metal oxide catalysts such as Ir oxide (IrO2) under the same conditions and appreciable catalytic wave at ∼1.52 V (vs. RHE). The optimal performance of the as-synthesized NiCo2O4 nanowires showed a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 under an overpotential of only 0.46 V and 20 mA cm-2 under an overpotential of 0.72 V, corresponding to a faradaic efficiency of nearly 100%. The at.-scale anal. of the NiCo2O4 nanowires was further conducted by spherical-aberration-cor. TEM. The highly exposed high-index facets and 1-dimensional (1D) configuration of the as-synthesized porous NiCo2O4 nanowires may be responsible for the high catalytic performance of H2O oxidn., which exhibit excellent activity and unique advantages for catalytic H2O splitting.

Pos. electrodes for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and the oxygen-evolution reaction (OER) play a crit. role in fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Tetragonal CoMn2O4 spinel nanoparticles have been grown on the surface of graphene sheets (CMOG) via a two-step synthesis. The ORR/OER catalytic characteristics of CMOG were studied with a rotating-disk electrode. Also a lithium-air primary cell having a non-aq. electrolyte and a rechargeable lithium-air cell with a Li-ion solid electrolyte sepg. a non-aq. anode electrolyte from an alk. aq. cathode electrolyte were assembled with a CMOG cathode and tested. The results indicate that a CMOG cathode can provide a catalytic platform of considerable activity for the ORR in both electrolytes and also for the OER in the aq. electrolyte.

Hierarchical nanostructures that can be directly grown on a conducting substrate are a new trend in the design of active materials for high-performance lithium-ion batteries. This article reports our design and fabrication of a three-dimensional hierarchical ZnCo2O4 nanostructure (3D-ZCO-NS) directly grown on Ni foams. The goose-feather-like ZnCo2O4 is bundled into a loose array structure with a large electrolyte contact area and good elec. and mech. connection to the current collector. Electrochem. measurements confirmed the good performance of the electrode for reversible Li+ storage (specific capacity 932 mA-h/g in the 50th cycle at 1 A/g) relative to a pasted electrode of 3D-ZCO-NSs (599 mA-h/g in the 50th cycle at 0.1 A/g).

The electrochem. behaviors of Cu2S nanowire array cathodes for lithium-ion battery applications reveal that they exhibit stable lithium ion insertion/extn. reversibility, high reversible lithium storage capacity, long cycle life and outstanding rate capability. Portable electronic devices which are ultrathin, lightwt. and even able to roll-up have attracted much attention. Herein, the authors report the design of flexible all-solid-state sym. supercapacitors by using 2 NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays supported on Ni foams as the electrodes. The as-fabricated sym. supercapacitors have excellent electrochem. performance with a high cell areal capacitance of 161 mF cm-2 at 1 mA cm-2. Good electrochem. performance stability over 3000 cycles was obtained even when the device was under harsh mech. conditions including both twisted and bent states. As-fabricated all-solid-state supercapacitors could be charged and power a com. light-emitting-diode, demonstrating their feasibility as an efficient energy storage component and self-powered micro/nano-system. The authors were able to grow NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays on many kinds of flexible substrates, including Ni foam, C cloth, Ti foil and polytetrafluoroethylene tape. The work here opens up opportunities for the device configuration for energy-storage devices in the future wearable electronic area and many other flexible, lightwt. and high performance functional nanoscale devices.

The ordered corn-like CuCo2O4 nanoforests were directly deposited on Ni foam by a hydrothermal/annealing method as a binder-free electrode for a sym. supercapacitor. The ordered one-dimensional nanostructure can enhance an effective electron transport. The abundant sub-structure can be used to contribute to increasing a large no. of active sites for Faradaic reactions. The binder-free loading can help to reduce the ohmic polarization during the charge/discharge process. For three-electrode configuration, the specific capacitance achieved 820 F/g at a c.d. of 2 mA/cm2 and long-term capacity retention of ∼94% after 1500 cycle. The sym. device gained a high energy d. of 17 W h/kg at a power d. of 480 W/kg.

Highly active, durable and cost-effective electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction play a key role on developing solar energy-conversion technologies. Here, we report a composite material consisting of CuCo2O4 nanoparticles anchored on nitrogenated reduced graphene oxide (CuCo2O4/NrGO) as a highly efficient oxygen evolution electrocatalyst in both alk. and neutral solns. for the first time. In 1 M KOH, 0.1 M KOH and 0.1 M PBS, CuCo2O4/NrGO catalyst exhibited a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 at a small overpotential of 0.36 V, 0.41 V and 1.15 V resp., which are better than those of RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts. The CuCo2O4/NrGO exhibited good stability under strong alk. conditions. The enhanced OER performance of CuCo2O4/NrGO is attributed to the presence of Cu2+ ions at the octahedral sites, redn. in the size of the CuCo2O4 nanoparticles as measured by the TEM, enhancement of electrochem. active surface area (ECSA), and synergetic effect between CuCo2O4 nanoparticles and NrGO sheets. This cost effective and highly efficient catalyst can possibly replace the expensive catalysts such as RuO2 and IrO2.

Highly O evolution reaction (OER)-active electrocatalysts often exhibit improved OER durability in the presence of C corrosion or oxidn. (COR) in the literature. The activity-durability coincidence of OER electrocatalysts was theor. understood by preferential depolarization in galvanostatic situations. At const.-current conditions for a system involving multiple reactions that are independent and competitive, the overpotential is detd. most dominantly by the most facile reaction so that the most facile reaction is responsible for a dominant portion of the overall current. Therefore, higher OER activity improves durability by mitigating the current responsible for COR. The activity-durability coincidence was then proved exptl. by comparing between 2 catalysts of the same chem. identity (MnCo2O4) in different dimensions (5 and 100 nm in size). Carbon corrosion responsible for inferior durability was suppressed in the smaller-dimension catalyst (MnCo2O4 in 5 nm) having more nos. of active sites per a fixed mass.

Constructing high-performance, economical and environmentally friendly photocatalysts remains a challenge for the efficient conversion of solar energy. Here, CuCo2O4 nanoparticles modified on TiO2 nanosheets have been designed and fabricated via a facile hydrothermal method followed by an in situ calcination process. The resultant 10%-CuCo2O4/TiO2 heterostructure exhibited superior photocatalytic activity under full spectra. The H generation rate can reach 4830 μmol/g-h under 300 W Xe lamp irradn., which is 32 times higher than that of pristine TiO2 and the highest fold increase of a binary TiO2-based non-noble system reported so far. Its apparent quantum yield (AQY) value can reach 11.5% at 365 nm. We demonstrate that there are chem. bonds formed at the interface between well-dispersed CuCo2O4 and TiO2 by XPS spectrometry and electronegativity theory, and the efficient sepn. of charge carriers due to the p-n junction adopting the interfacial Ti-O-Cu/Co bonds is crucial for the improved performance and photostability. This work develops possibilities to prep. feasible CuCo2O4-based heterostructures for energy conversion.

Co3O4, which is of mixed valences Co2+ and Co3+, has been extensively investigated as an efficient electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The proper control of Co2+/Co3+ ratio in Co3O4 could lead to modifications on its electronic and thus catalytic properties. Herein, we designed an efficient Co3O4-based OER electrocatalyst by a plasma-engraving strategy, which not only produced higher surface area, but also generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 surface with more Co2+ formed. The increased surface area ensures the Co3O4 has more sites for OER, and generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 surface improve the electronic cond. and create more active defects for OER. Compared to pristine Co3O4, the engraved Co3O4 exhibits a much higher c.d. and a lower onset potential. The specific activity of the plasma-engraved Co3O4 nanosheets (0.055 mA/cm2BET at 1.6 V) is 10 times higher than that of pristine Co3O4, which is contributed by the surface oxygen vacancies.

Porous cobalt oxide nanoplates enriched with oxygen vacancies are synthesized using a ligand-assisted polyol redn. method. This method enables large-scale synthesis that offers superior uniformity, soln. dispersity and controllable concn. of oxygen vacancies on surface. The large surface area of porous cobalt oxide nanoplates together with enriched oxygen vacancies provide more active sites, which promote faster exchange of intermediates and more efficient electron transfer. The as prepd. cobalt oxide nanoplates manifest oxygen evolution reaction (OER) overpotential as low as 306 mV at 10 mA/cm2 in 1 M KOH, which is superior to the values of most reported Co-based electrocatalysts.

It is of high significance to design efficient, low-cost and durable electrocatalysts for the reaction (OER) in alk. soln. In this communication, we report the development of CuCo2O4 microflowers directly on nickel foam (CuCo2O4/NF) as an efficient and durable electrocatalyst for OER. Such CuCo2O4/NF demands overpotential of only 296 mV to drive a geometrical catalytic c.d. of 20 mA/cm2, 73 mV and 145 mV less than that for Co3O4/NF and NF, resp., which are better than that of RuO2/NF. Furthermore, CuCo2O4/NF presents an excellent long-term electrochem. durability maintaining the activity at overpotential of 240 mV for 10 h.

Well-aligned CuO
[email protected]
nanosheet core-shell array was successfully fabricated on C fibers by multi-step electrodeposition combined with thermal treatment and applied as the binder- and conductive-agent-free anode for O evolution reaction (OER) in H2O electrolysis process. Such an anode revealed an overpotential of 258 ± 3.2 mV at a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 in 1.0 mol L-1 KOH soln., which is much lower than that of pure CuO nanowires or Co3O4 nanosheets based electrode. This should be attributed to the smart hybridization of CuO nanowires and Co3O4 nanosheets into hierarchical core/shell array configuration which could largely increase the amt. of contact areas between electrolyte and active sites. Also, the Cu2+ in CuO/Co3O4 composite was oxidized to Cu3+ components during the OER process, which should serve as the new catalytic active sites for OER. It is expected to provide a novel route to prep. such a core-shell electrocatalyst with high performance for H2O splitting.

In this work, we report a novel integrated inorg. membrane electrode assembly (I2MEA) for anion exchange membrane (AEM) water electrolysis by using inorg. Mg-Al layered double hydroxides (Mg-Al LDHs) as an ionic conductor. Mg-Al LDHs synthesized by a two-step approach exhibit high hydroxide ion cond. and superior stability. The resultant ionic conducting nanoparticles are cold-pressed to form a membrane and mixed with a non-precious electrocatalyst to form the catalyst layer onto each side of the membrane. As such, an I2MEA is formed and used in a water electrolysis setup. It is shown that the present water electrolysis results in a max. c.d. of 208 mA cm-2 with 0.1 M NaOH as the electrolyte and a cutoff voltage of 2.2 V at 70°C. More impressively, using 0.1 M Na2CO3 as the electrolyte, the I2MEAs can continuously electrolyze at 80 mA cm-2 for 600 h with a decay rate of as low as 100μV h-1. This superior stability is attributed to the integrated structure that allows hydroxide ions to transport smoothly.

In this work, a new LDPE based anion-exchange membrane was prepd. by UV-induced grafting of vinylbenzyl chloride (VBC) functional monomers and their successive conversion into quaternary ammonium sites with 1,4-diazabicyclo(2.2.2)octane (Dabco). After thin film formation this material was used to prep. a MEA (membrane electrode assembly) for use in an alk. membrane water electrolyzer. The membrane was primarily characterized by electron microscopy, FTIR and solid state NMR techniques in order to det. its structural and phase properties whereas electrochem. parameters were evaluated and compared to a com. benchmark membrane. Exptl. data showed that the electrochem. performance of the LDPE-VBC-Dabco membrane was comparable to that measured for the best com. material, and enabled its use in an electrolytic cell for hydrogen prodn. The results obtained in the electrolytic cell showed a const. hydrogen prodn. rate of about 30 cc/min over more than 500 h. However, the long time stability of the LDPE-g-VBC-Dabco membrane needs still to be improved in the alk. environment of the working cell.

The authors developed high-performance anion-exchange membrane H2O electrolysis (AEMWE) by studying various parameters. To enhance AEMWE performance, the effects of the membrane-electrode assembly (MEA) fabrication method, operating conditions, and MEA parameters were examd. As a result of the optimization and the use of FAA-3-50 and FAA-3-Br as the AEM and anion-exchange ionomer, resp., AEMWE showed the highest performance reported thus far. Single-cell tests and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy results indicate that optimized AEMWE minimized the ohmic, charge-transfer, and mass transport resistances. Overall, by examg. the AEMWE parameters, the authors were able to improve the electrochem. reactions, namely, the O evolution reaction and H evolution reaction, and achieved outstanding performance.

The oxygen evolution catalyst used was based on Cu0.7Co2.3O4 particle 20-30 nm in size, synthesized through a thermal decompn. method. A membrane electrode assembly was prepd. with the resultant membrane as electrolyte, the Cu0.7Co2.3O4 nano-particles as the anode catalyst and Ni nano-powders as the hydrogen evolution catalyst. SEM observations showed that the catalysts were well dispersed on the electrodes. The polarization curves exhibited onset voltages for water electrolysis of around 1.5 V. Low-temp. electricity-driven H2O splitting is an established technol. for H prodn. However, the two main types, proton exchange membrane (PEM) and liq. alk. electrolysis, have limitations. For instance, PEM electrolysis requires a high amt. of costly Pt-group-metal (PGM) catalysts, and liq. alk. electrolysis is not well suited for intermittent operation. Herein the authors report a highly efficient alk. polymer electrolysis design, which uses a membrane-electrode assembly (MEA) based on low-cost transition-metal catalysts and an anion exchange membrane (AEM). This system exhibited similar performance to the one achievable with PGM catalysts. Also, it is very suitable for intermittent power operation, durable, and able to efficiently operate at differential pressure up to 3 MPa. This system combines the benefits of PEM and liq. alk. technologies allowing the scalable prodn. of low-cost H from renewable sources.

Lim, Ahyoun; Kim, Hyoung-juhn; Henkensmeier, Dirk; Jong Yoo, Sung; Young Kim, Jin; Young Lee, So; Sung, Yung-Eun; Jang, Jong Hyun; Park, Hyun S.

Polymer electrolyte membrane water electrolysis has been proposed to address prodn. of high purity hydrogen for storage of excess renewable energy. Among them, alk. electrolyte membrane based water electrolysis (AEMWE) has an advantage in the aspect of material costs, e.g. from non-noble catalysts and membrane, but suffers from lower performance compared to proton exchange membrane based water electrolysis (PEMWE). However, there are fewer researches on single cell MEA and operation study compared to material research to enhance AEMWE performance. Here, we analyze the effect of the cell construction and operation factors, i.e MEA pressing, torque of cell assembly, electrolyte pre-feed methods, and operation temp., to obtain high performance in AEMWE single cell operation. 97.5% current improves at 1.8 V by applying optimized torque. 94% decrease of ohmic resistance are achieved from electrolyte pre-feeding. 50 mA cm-2 of c.d. is enhanced at 0.591 V of overvoltage per 10°C temp. increase due to higher ionic cond. and reaction kinetics. These factors significantly affect internal factors such as not only material property during operation but also, catalysts structure and contact in MEA, leading 4.3 times progress of c.d. from 0.242 to 1.045 A cm-2 at 1.8 Vcell.

Pyrochlore electrocatalysts for efficient alkaline water electrolysis
Parrondo, Javier; George, Morgan; Capuano, Christopher; Ayers, Katherine E.; Ramani, Vijay
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability
(
2015
),

Elec. conducting metal oxides with the pyrochlore structure (A2B2O7-y, with A = Pb or Bi and B = Ru, Ir or Os) were synthesized via pptn./crystn. in alk. medium and/or via solid-state reaction. The electrocatalytic activity for the O evolution reaction (OER) in 0.1 M KOH was studied using a rotating disk electrode. Lead and Bi ruthenate pyrochlores showed significantly lower overpotentials for the OER than the state-of-the-art IrO2 catalyst. Specific activities (at 1.5 V vs. RHE) of 3.0 ± 0.2 A m-2, 1.3 ± 0.2 A m-2 and 0.06 ± 0.01 A m-2 were obtained for Pb2Ru2O6.5, Bi2.4Ru1.6O7, and IrO2, resp. Specific activities for iridate-based pyrochlores (0.3-0.5 A m-2) were 5-10 times lower than those for ruthenate-based pyrochlores. Lead osmate pyrochlore showed the lowest OER activity among all the pyrochlores evaluated, with a specific activity of 0.10 ± 0.07 A m-2. Probably the reaction path for the OER involves several O intermediate species (-O2-, -OOH, -OO2-, -OH) bonded to the B-site (Ru, Ir or Os) in the pyrochlore, and that the catalytic activity depends on the bonding strength between the B-cation site and the O species. This hypothesis was supported by the fact that OER activity correlated with Ru concn. in Pb-rich lead ruthenate pyrochlores. The decrease of the specific OER activity depended on the occupancy of the 3d orbitals and on the period in the periodic table occupied by the B-cation. The OER activity decreased for pyrochlores with B cations having more d electrons than Ru, and when the B cation occupied period 6. The obsd. trend in activity was similar to that obsd. for the O redn. reaction on transition metals, and was related to the strength of the bonding between the adsorbed O species and the B-cation. The exceptional OER activity and stability of lead ruthenate pyrochlore catalysts were evaluated in a solid-state alk. H2O electrolyzer. The overpotentials obtained were 0.1-0.2 V lower than for IrO2 and the performance was stable for at least 200 h.

Low-temp. electricity-driven water splitting is an established technol. for hydrogen prodn., yet only few materials are able to catalyze hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions in the same medium. Herein, ultrathin CoP nanosheets (CoP NS) as durable bifunctional catalysts for electrochem. water splitting are reported. The OER and HER activity for CoP NS/C reaching 10 mA/cm2 needs an overpotential of only 0.277 V and 0.111 V in a basic soln. What's more, when integrated into a practical anion exchange membrane water electrolysis cell using CoP NS as both anode and cathode catalysts, a c.d. of 335 mA/cm2 at 1.8 V is achieved, which is rather competitive to the state-of-the-art Pt/IrO2 catalyst. This work would open a new avenue to explore the use of transition metal phosphides as green and attractive bifunctional catalysts toward mass prodn. of hydrogen fuel for applications.

Alk. anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) is considered to be an alternative to proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE), owing to the use of non-noble meta/metal oxides in AEMWE. Here, we report a highly durable and low-cost AEM-based electrolysis cell with active spinel ferrite catalysts for hydrogen prodn. Ce-substituted MnFe2O4 was synthesized by a combustion method and investigated as the electro catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Substitution of Ce in the cubic lattice of MnFe2O4 increases the cond. of CexMnFe(2-x)O4, which results in a neg. shift in the OER onset potential. At 25 °C, the single cell with Ce0.2MnFe1.8O4 exhibited a c.d. of 300 mA cm-2 at 1.8 V. Notably, Ce0.2MnFe1.8O4 demonstrates a durability of >100 h in continuous electrolysis.

To improve the cell performance for alk. anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE), the effects of the amt. of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) non-ionomeric binder in the anode and the hot-pressing conditions during the fabrication of the membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) on cell performances are studied. The electrochem. impedance data indicates that hot-pressing at 50° for 1 min during MEA construction can reduce the polarization resistance of AEMWE by ∼12%, and increase the initial water electrolysis c.d. at 1.8 V (from 195 to 243 mA/cm2). The electrochem. polarization and impedance results also suggest that the AEMWE performance is significantly affected by the content of PTFE binder in the anode electrode, and the optimal content is found to be 9 wt.% between 5 and 20 wt.%. The AEMWE device fabricated with the optimized parameters exhibits good water splitting performance (299 mA/cm2 at 1.8 V) without noticeable degrdn. in voltage cycling operations.

Herein, we investigate the effects of catholyte feed method and anode binder content on the characteristics of anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) to construct a high-performance electrolyzer, revealing that the initial AEMWE performance is significantly improved by pre-feeding 0.5M aq. KOH to the cathode. The highest long-term activity during repeated voltage cycling is obsd. for AEMWE operation in the dry cathode mode, for which the best long-term performance among membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) featuring polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) binder-impregnated (5-20wt%) anodes is detected for a PTFE content of 20wt%. MEAs with low PTFE content (5 and 9wt%) demonstrate high initial performance, rapid performance decay, and significant catalyst loss from the electrode during long-term operation, whereas the MEA with 20wt% PTFE allows stable water electrolysis for over 1600 voltage cycles. Optimization of cell operating conditions (i.e., operation in dry cathode mode at an optimum anode binder content following an initial soln. feed) achieves an enhanced water splitting c.d. (1.07Acm-2 at 1.8V) and stable long-term AEMWE performance (0.01% c.d. redn. per voltage cycle).

A review. Hydrogen is considered to be the most viable energy carrier for the future. Producing hydrogen from ethanol steam reforming would not only be environmentally friendly but also would open new opportunities for utilization of renewable resources, which are globally available. This paper reviews the current state of the steam reforming process of ethanol, examines different catalysts, and, finally, makes a comparative anal. Different catalysts were used for the steam reforming of ethanol. Depending on the type of catalysts, reaction conditions, and the catalyst prepn. method, ethanol conversion and hydrogen prodn. vary greatly. Co/ZnO, ZnO, Rh/Al2O3, Rh/CeO2, and Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 performed the best, in regard to the steam reforming of ethanol. Currently, hydrogen prodn. from ethanol steam reforming is still in the research and development stage.

Because of the existence of infrastructures all around the world, the use of fossil resources as raw materials for hydrogen prodn. can be a midterm soln. in the implementation of hydrogen as a transport fuel. Therefore, the fuel processing technol. used for the prodn. of hydrogen should produce the lowest amt. of greenhouse gases, with the highest energy efficiency and the lowest environmental impact. In this work, several options for hydrogen prodn. from fossil fuels are evaluated: steam reforming, autothermal reforming of hydrocarbons, coal gasification, and methane decompn. A system for the capture of CO2 is supposed to be integrated in the reforming and gasification processes. This study evaluates the overall life cycle greenhouse gas emissions, the fossil energy consumption, and the environmental impact for the current and future energy scenarios. The autothermal reforming, decompn. of natural gas, and coal gasification are the best options from all of the points of view, while extrapolations to future scenarios predict very similar impacts. The economic anal. of methane decompn. processes reveals that the carbon selling price and the conversion of methane are the main factors influencing the cost-efficiency of produced hydrogen.

A review. Alk. water electrolysis is one of the easiest methods for hydrogen prodn., offering the advantage of simplicity. The challenges for widespread use of water electrolysis are to reduce energy consumption, cost and maintenance and to increase reliability, durability and safety. This literature review examines the current state of knowledge and technol. of hydrogen prodn. by water electrolysis and identifies areas where R&D effort is needed in order to improve this technol. Following an overview of the fundamentals of alk. water electrolysis, an elec. circuit analogy of resistances in the electrolysis system is introduced. The resistances are classified into three categories, namely the elec. resistances, the reaction resistances and the transport resistances. This is followed by a thorough anal. of each of the resistances, by means of thermodn. and kinetics, to provide a scientific guidance to minimising the resistance in order to achieve a greater efficiency of alk. water electrolysis. The thermodn. anal. defines various electrolysis efficiencies based on theor. energy input and cell voltage, resp. These efficiencies are then employed to compare different electrolysis cell designs and to identify the means to overcome the key resistances for efficiency improvement. The kinetic anal. reveals the dependence of reaction resistances on the alk. concn., ion transfer, and reaction sites on the electrode surface, the latter is detd. by the electrode materials. A quant. relationship between the cell voltage components and c.d. is established, which links all the resistances and manifests the importance of reaction resistances and bubble resistances. The important effect of gas bubbles formed on the electrode surface and the need to minimise the ion transport resistance are highlighted. The historical development and continuous improvement in the alk. water electrolysis technol. are examd. and different water electrolysis technologies are systematically compared using a set of the practical parameters derived from the thermodn. and kinetic analyses. In addn. to the efficiency improvements, the needs for redn. in equipment and maintenance costs, and improvement in reliability and durability are also established. The future research needs are also discussed from the aspects of electrode materials, electrolyte additives and bubble management, serving as a comprehensive guide for continuous development of the water electrolysis technol.

Ultra-pure hydrogen to feed a low temp. Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) or a high temp. Solid Oxide Fuel Cell (SOFC) can be produced by water electrolysis, either in a Proton Exchange Membrane Electrolysis Cell (PEMEC) working at low temps. (25-110 °C) or in a Solid Oxide Electrolysis Cell (SOEC) working at high temps. (600-950 °C). Both processes will be presented and discussed comparatively in terms of energy efficiencies, taking into account the working conditions at a low (70-80 °C) or a high (800 °C) temp. and at a given c.d., conditions which are far from the thermodn. equil. (no current flowing). Conversely to what is often written in the literature, the elec. energy efficiency of a SOEC never exceeds 100% and is comparable to that of a PEMEC, reaching in both cases 60-70% depending on the working conditions. In addn. the elec. efficiency of a hydrogen/oxygen fuel cell working at a low temp. (PEMFC) or high temp. (SOFC) will be calcd. allowing us to evaluate the round-trip energy efficiency of a hydrogen redox battery, such as a Unitized Regenerative Fuel Cell (URFC) for storage of intermittent energy. Some exptl. examples of URFC working at low (PEM) or high (SOC) temps. from recent publications will be presented and their energy efficiency will be estd. according to our theor. calcns.

The development of medium size solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) water electrolyzers is of great practical interest for on-board prodn. of oxygen in submarines and for energy storage purposes in space applications. While the SPE technol. has largely demonstrated its potential on the lab. scale, very little information is available in the literature on the technol. characteristics and electrochem. performances of larger water electrolyzers. The authors present part of the experience that the authors gained in the development of medium size electrolysis units. A 0.5 kW SPE water electrolyzer was designed and tested. Its performance is discussed with respect to technol. design (fluids and current distribution) and operating conditions.

Proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE) is an advanced and effective soln. to the primary energy storage technologies. A better understanding of performance and durability of PEMWE is crit. for the engineers and researchers to further advance this technol. for its market penetration, and for the manufacturers of PEM water electrolyzers to implement quality control procedures for the prodn. line or on-site process monitoring/diagnosis. This paper reviews the published works on performance degrdns. and mitigation strategies for PEMWE. Sources of degrdn. for individual components are introduced. With degrdn. causes discussed and degrdn. mechanisms examd., the review emphasizes on feasible strategies to mitigate the components degrdn. To avoid lengthy real lifetime degrdn. tests and their high costs, the importance of accelerated stress tests and protocols is highlighted for various components. In the end, R&D directions are proposed to move the PEMWE technol. forward to become a key element in future energy scenarios.

The authors report high-performance, durable alk. membrane H2O electrolysis in a solid-state cell. An anion exchange membrane (AEM) and catalyst layer ionomer for hydroxide ion conduction were used without the addn. of liq. electrolyte. At 50°, an AEM electrolysis cell using Ir oxide as the anode catalyst and Pt black as the cathode catalyst exhibited a c.d. of 399 mA/cm2 at 1.80 V. The durability of the AEM-based electrolysis cell could be improved by incorporating a highly durable ionomer in the catalyst layer and optimizing the H2O feed configuration. The authors demonstrated an AEM-based electrolysis cell with a lifetime of >535 h. These 1st-time results of H2O electrolysis in a solid-state membrane cell are promising for low-cost, scalable H prodn.

Cu incorporated Co3O4 (CuxCo3-xO4, 0 ≤ x < 1) nanoparticles were prepd. using a thermal decompn. method. Properties of the CuxCo3-xO4, such as morphol., particle sizes, crystallite structure and cation distribution, were characterized with SEM, TEM, XRD and EDX. The CuxCo3-xO4 particles, with various x values, are cubic spinel nanoparticles, with av. size of 20-30 nm. Incorporation of Cu in the spinel lattice of Co3O4 shifted the Co3+/Co4+ redox peak as well as the onset point for OER to more neg. potentials, which may be related to inversion of Cu2+ into the octahedral sites. Amongst all samples studied, Cu0.7Co2.3O4 was the most active for OER. The CuxCo3-xO4 electrodes exhibited satisfying stability during repetitive cyclic voltammetry. A membrane electrode assembly, using 3 mg cm-2 Cu0.7Co2.3O4 on the anode, demonstrated, in an alk. membrane H2O electrolyzer, a high c.d. performance of 1 A cm-2 at a voltage of 1.8 V in 1 mol dm-3 KOH at 25°.

Spinel-structured transition metal oxides are promising non-precious-metal electrocatalysts for oxygen electrocatalysis in rechargeable metal-air batteries. Porous cobalt manganese oxide (CMO) nanocubes are applied as the cathode electrocatalyst in rechargeable seawater batteries, which are a hybrid-type Na-air battery with an open-structured cathode and a seawater catholyte. The porous CMO nanocubes were synthesized by the pyrolysis of a Prussian blue analog, Mn3[Co(CN)6]2·nH2O, during air-annealing, which generated numerous pores between the final spinel-type CMO nanoparticles. The porous CMO electrocatalyst improved the redox reactions, such as the oxygen evolution/redn. reactions, at the cathode in the seawater batteries. The battery that used CMO displayed a voltage gap of ∼0.53 V, relatively small compared to that of the batteries employing com. Pt/C (∼0.64 V) and Ir/C (∼0.73 V) nanoparticles and without any catalyst (∼1.05 V) at the initial cycle. This improved performance was due to the large surface area (catalytically active sites) and the high oxidn. states of the randomly distributed Co and Mn cations in the CMO. Using a hard carbon anode, the Na-metal-free seawater battery exhibited a good cycle performance with an av. discharge voltage of ∼2.7 V and a discharge capacity of ∼190 mAh g-1hardcarbon during 100 cycles (energy efficiencies of 74-79%).

Herein the authors report a facile and direct synthesis of porous NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays (NWAs) with robust mech. adhesion to conductive electrodes by a simple two-step method. Upon complete pyrolysis of the Co-Ni-hydroxide precursor, high-quality cryst. NiCo2O4 is achieved. The porous NiCo2O4 nanowires are highly active for catalytic H2O oxidn. when serving as the working electrodes without any external materials (binder and/or C black), as evidenced by exhibiting higher catalytic c.d. for H2O oxidn. compared to precious metal oxide catalysts such as Ir oxide (IrO2) under the same conditions and appreciable catalytic wave at ∼1.52 V (vs. RHE). The optimal performance of the as-synthesized NiCo2O4 nanowires showed a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 under an overpotential of only 0.46 V and 20 mA cm-2 under an overpotential of 0.72 V, corresponding to a faradaic efficiency of nearly 100%. The at.-scale anal. of the NiCo2O4 nanowires was further conducted by spherical-aberration-cor. TEM. The highly exposed high-index facets and 1-dimensional (1D) configuration of the as-synthesized porous NiCo2O4 nanowires may be responsible for the high catalytic performance of H2O oxidn., which exhibit excellent activity and unique advantages for catalytic H2O splitting.

Hierarchical nanostructures that can be directly grown on a conducting substrate are a new trend in the design of active materials for high-performance lithium-ion batteries. This article reports our design and fabrication of a three-dimensional hierarchical ZnCo2O4 nanostructure (3D-ZCO-NS) directly grown on Ni foams. Portable electronic devices which are ultrathin, lightwt. and even able to roll-up have attracted much attention. Herein, the authors report the design of flexible all-solid-state sym. supercapacitors by using 2 NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays supported on Ni foams as the electrodes. The as-fabricated sym. supercapacitors have excellent electrochem. performance with a high cell areal capacitance of 161 mF cm-2 at 1 mA cm-2. Good electrochem. performance stability over 3000 cycles was obtained even when the device was under harsh mech. conditions including both twisted and bent states. As-fabricated all-solid-state supercapacitors could be charged and power a com. light-emitting-diode, demonstrating their feasibility as an efficient energy storage component and self-powered micro/nano-system. The authors were able to grow NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays on many kinds of flexible substrates, including Ni foam, C cloth, Ti foil and polytetrafluoroethylene tape. The work here opens up opportunities for the device configuration for energy-storage devices in the future wearable electronic area and many other flexible, lightwt. and high performance functional nanoscale devices.

The ordered corn-like CuCo2O4 nanoforests were directly deposited on Ni foam by a hydrothermal/annealing method as a binder-free electrode for a sym. supercapacitor. The ordered one-dimensional nanostructure can enhance an effective electron transport. The abundant sub-structure can be used to contribute to increasing a large no. of active sites for Faradaic reactions. The binder-free loading can help to reduce the ohmic polarization during the charge/discharge process. For three-electrode configuration, the specific capacitance achieved 820 F/g at a c.d. of 2 mA/cm2 and long-term capacity retention of ∼94% after 1500 cycle. The sym. device gained a high energy d. of 17 W h/kg at a power d. of 480 W/kg.

Highly active, durable and cost-effective electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction play a key role on developing solar energy-conversion technologies. Here, we report a composite material consisting of CuCo2O4 nanoparticles anchored on nitrogenated reduced graphene oxide (CuCo2O4/NrGO) as a highly efficient oxygen evolution electrocatalyst in both alk. and neutral solns. for the first time. In 1 M KOH, 0.1 M KOH and 0.1 M PBS, CuCo2O4/NrGO catalyst exhibited a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 at a small overpotential of 0.36 V, 0.41 V and 1.15 V resp., which are better than those of RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts. The CuCo2O4/NrGO exhibited good stability under strong alk. conditions. The enhanced OER performance of CuCo2O4/NrGO is attributed to the presence of Cu2+ ions at the octahedral sites, redn. in the size of the CuCo2O4 nanoparticles as measured by the TEM, enhancement of electrochem. active surface area (ECSA), and synergetic effect between CuCo2O4 nanoparticles and NrGO sheets. This cost effective and highly efficient catalyst can possibly replace the expensive catalysts such as RuO2 and IrO2.

Highly O evolution reaction (OER)-active electrocatalysts often exhibit improved OER durability in the presence of C corrosion or oxidn. (COR) in the literature. The activity-durability coincidence of OER electrocatalysts was theor. understood by preferential depolarization in galvanostatic situations. At const.-current conditions for a system involving multiple reactions that are independent and competitive, the overpotential is detd. most dominantly by the most facile reaction so that the most facile reaction is responsible for a dominant portion of the overall current. Therefore, higher OER activity improves durability by mitigating the current responsible for COR. The activity-durability coincidence was then proved exptl. by comparing between 2 catalysts of the same chem. identity (MnCo2O4) in different dimensions (5 and 100 nm in size). Carbon corrosion responsible for inferior durability was suppressed in the smaller-dimension catalyst (MnCo2O4 in 5 nm) having more nos. of active sites per a fixed mass.

Constructing high-performance, economical and environmentally friendly photocatalysts remains a challenge for the efficient conversion of solar energy. Here, CuCo2O4 nanoparticles modified on TiO2 nanosheets have been designed and fabricated via a facile hydrothermal method followed by an in situ calcination process. The resultant 10%-CuCo2O4/TiO2 heterostructure exhibited superior photocatalytic activity under full spectra. The H generation rate can reach 4830 μmol/g-h under 300 W Xe lamp irradn., which is 32 times higher than that of pristine TiO2 and the highest fold increase of a binary TiO2-based non-noble system reported so far. Its apparent quantum yield (AQY) value can reach 11.5% at 365 nm. We demonstrate that there are chem. bonds formed at the interface between well-dispersed CuCo2O4 and TiO2 by XPS spectrometry and electronegativity theory, and the efficient sepn. of charge carriers due to the p-n junction adopting the interfacial Ti-O-Cu/Co bonds is crucial for the improved performance and photostability. This work develops possibilities to prep. feasible CuCo2O4-based heterostructures for energy conversion.

Co3O4, which is of mixed valences Co2+ and Co3+, has been extensively investigated as an efficient electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The proper control of Co2+/Co3+ ratio in Co3O4 could lead to modifications on its electronic and thus catalytic properties. Herein, we designed an efficient Co3O4-based OER electrocatalyst by a plasma-engraving strategy, which not only produced higher surface area, but also generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 surface with more Co2+ formed. The increased surface area ensures the Co3O4 has more sites for OER, and generated oxygen vacancies on Co3O4 surface improve the electronic cond. and create more active defects for OER. Compared to pristine Co3O4, the engraved Co3O4 exhibits a much higher c.d. and a lower onset potential. The specific activity of the plasma-engraved Co3O4 nanosheets (0.055 mA/cm2BET at 1.6 V) is 10 times higher than that of pristine Co3O4, which is contributed by the surface oxygen vacancies.

In this work, we report a novel integrated inorg. membrane electrode assembly (I2MEA) for anion exchange membrane (AEM) water electrolysis by using inorg. Mg-Al layered double hydroxides (Mg-Al LDHs) as an ionic conductor. Mg-Al LDHs synthesized by a two-step approach exhibit high hydroxide ion cond. and superior stability. The resultant ionic conducting nanoparticles are cold-pressed to form a membrane and mixed with a non-precious electrocatalyst to form the catalyst layer onto each side of the membrane. As such, an I2MEA is formed and used in a water electrolysis setup. It is shown that the present water electrolysis results in a max. c.d. of 208 mA cm-2 with 0.1 M NaOH as the electrolyte and a cutoff voltage of 2.2 V at 70°C. More impressively, using 0.1 M Na2CO3 as the electrolyte, the I2MEAs can continuously electrolyze at 80 mA cm-2 for 600 h with a decay rate of as low as 100μV h-1. This superior stability is attributed to the integrated structure that allows hydroxide ions to transport smoothly.

Low-temp. electricity-driven H2O splitting is an established technol. for H prodn. However, the two main types, proton exchange membrane (PEM) and liq. alk. electrolysis, have limitations. For instance, PEM electrolysis requires a high amt. of costly Pt-group-metal (PGM) catalysts, and liq. alk. electrolysis is not well suited for intermittent operation. Herein the authors report a highly efficient alk. polymer electrolysis design, which uses a membrane-electrode assembly (MEA) based on low-cost transition-metal catalysts and an anion exchange membrane (AEM). This system exhibited similar performance to the one achievable with PGM catalysts. Also, it is very suitable for intermittent power operation, durable, and able to efficiently operate at differential pressure up to 3 MPa. This system combines the benefits of PEM and liq. alk. technologies allowing the scalable prodn. of low-cost H from renewable sources.

Elec. conducting metal oxides with the pyrochlore structure (A2B2O7-y, with A = Pb or Bi and B = Ru, Ir or Os) were synthesized via pptn./crystn. in alk. medium and/or via solid-state reaction. The electrocatalytic activity for the O evolution reaction (OER) in 0.1 M KOH was studied using a rotating disk electrode. Lead and Bi ruthenate pyrochlores showed significantly lower overpotentials for the OER than the state-of-the-art IrO2 catalyst. Specific activities (at 1.5 V vs. RHE) of 3.0 ± 0.2 A m-2, 1.3 ± 0.2 A m-2 and 0.06 ± 0.01 A m-2 were obtained for Pb2Ru2O6.5, Bi2.4Ru1.6O7, and IrO2, resp. Specific activities for iridate-based pyrochlores (0.3-0.5 A m-2) were 5-10 times lower than those for ruthenate-based pyrochlores. Lead osmate pyrochlore showed the lowest OER activity among all the pyrochlores evaluated, with a specific activity of 0.10 ± 0.07 A m-2. Probably the reaction path for the OER involves several O intermediate species (-O2-, -OOH, -OO2-, -OH) bonded to the B-site (Ru, Ir or Os) in the pyrochlore, and that the catalytic activity depends on the bonding strength between the B-cation site and the O species. This hypothesis was supported by the fact that OER activity correlated with Ru concn. in Pb-rich lead ruthenate pyrochlores. The decrease of the specific OER activity depended on the occupancy of the 3d orbitals and on the period in the periodic table occupied by the B-cation. The OER activity decreased for pyrochlores with B cations having more d electrons than Ru, and when the B cation occupied period 6. The obsd. trend in activity was similar to that obsd. for the O redn. reaction on transition metals, and was related to the strength of the bonding between the adsorbed O species and the B-cation. The exceptional OER activity and stability of lead ruthenate pyrochlore catalysts were evaluated in a solid-state alk. H2O electrolyzer. The overpotentials obtained were 0.1-0.2 V lower than for IrO2 and the performance was stable for at least 200 h.

Cho, Min Kyung; Park, Hee-Young; Choe, Seunghoe; Yoo, Sung Jong; Kim, Jin Young; Kim, Hyoung-Juhn; Henkensmeier, Dirk; Lee, So Young; Sung, Yung-Eun; Park, Hyun S.; Jang, Jong Hyun
Journal of Power Sources
(
2017
),
347
(
),
283-290
CODEN:
JPSODZ
; ISSN:
0378-7753
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
To improve the cell performance for alk. anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE), the effects of the amt. of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) non-ionomeric binder in the anode and the hot-pressing conditions during the fabrication of the membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) on cell performances are studied. The electrochem. impedance data indicates that hot-pressing at 50° for 1 min during MEA construction can reduce the polarization resistance of AEMWE by ∼12%, and increase the initial water electrolysis c.d. at 1.8 V (from 195 to 243 mA/cm2). The electrochem. polarization and impedance results also suggest that the AEMWE performance is significantly affected by the content of PTFE binder in the anode electrode, and the optimal content is found to be 9 wt.% between 5 and 20 wt.%. The AEMWE device fabricated with the optimized parameters exhibits good water splitting performance (299 mA/cm2 at 1.8 V) without noticeable degrdn. in voltage cycling operations.

Alkaline anion exchange membrane water electrolysis: Effects of electrolyte feed method and electrode binder content
Cho, Min Kyung; Park, Hee-Young; Lee, Hye Jin; Kim, Hyoung-Juhn; Lim, Ahyoun; Henkensmeier, Dirk; Yoo, Sung Jong; Kim, Jin Young; Lee, So Young; Park, Hyun S.; Jang, Jong Hyun

),

(

CODEN:
JPSODZ
; ISSN:
0378-7753
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Herein, we investigate the effects of catholyte feed method and anode binder content on the characteristics of anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) to construct a high-performance electrolyzer, revealing that the initial AEMWE performance is significantly improved by pre-feeding 0.5M aq. KOH to the cathode. The highest long-term activity during repeated voltage cycling is obsd. for AEMWE operation in the dry cathode mode, for which the best long-term performance among membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) featuring polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) binder-impregnated (5-20wt%) anodes is detected for a PTFE content of 20wt%. MEAs with low PTFE content (5 and 9wt%) demonstrate high initial performance, rapid performance decay, and significant catalyst loss from the electrode during long-term operation, whereas the MEA with 20wt% PTFE allows stable water electrolysis for over 1600 voltage cycles. Optimization of cell operating conditions (i.e., operation in dry cathode mode at an optimum anode binder content following an initial soln. feed) achieves an enhanced water splitting c.d. (1.07Acm-2 at 1.8V) and stable long-term AEMWE performance (0.01% c.d. redn. per voltage cycle).
